Award.AwardTitle: 2015-2017 SUNY LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate at Binghamton University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in diversifying the STEM workforce through their efforts at significantly increasing the numbers of students from historically underrepresented minority populations to successfully complete high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. The LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate (LSAMP-BD) activity provides two-year support at the postbaccalaurate level for students from historically underrepresented minority populations to matriculate in STEM graduate programs with the ultimate goal of earning a doctoral degree in a STEM discipline. Participants are selected from LSAMP institutions nationwide. The State University of New York System Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (SUNY LSAMP) under the leadership of Stony Brook University has chosen Binghamton University as the host site for the 2015-2017 BD program in which a cohort of twelve LSAMP certified students selected from the national pool will engage in STEM research, academics and professional development activities leading to STEM Master's and Doctoral degree completion. The BD program at Binghamton University provides a comprehensive set of support services that monitors student progress, builds a strong BD community, and increases BD students' academic and professional skills.

Nine cohorts of students have matriculated in SUNY LSAMP graduate LSAMP-BD programs at Stony Brook, Buffalo, Binghamton and Albany since 2006. The programs promote systemic change in graduate education practices and policy in ways that increase the success of individual students on the doctoral pathway and the effectiveness of STEM graduate programs, continuing the goal of diversifying America's STEM workforce. The program at Binghamton University will be externally evaluated and students will be tracked throughout the program and into STEM careers following completion of STEM doctoral degree programs. Collaborations with other STEM networks and resources internal and external to the state as well as other graduate programs, such as NSF's Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP), Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) and institutional resources will further ensure that students complete the STEM terminal degree.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bridge to the Doctorate Outcomes- Binghamton University 

 

The 2015 State University of New York (SUNY) Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Cohort at Binghamton University (BU) successfully recruited 14 BD Fellows. The 14 BD Fellows were selected from 45 applicants, representing 31 LSAMP undergraduate institutions. The 12 Fellows were admitted into seven different majors at BU: Mathematics (2), System Science and Industrial Engineering (4), Physics (1), Computer Science (1), Biological Sciences (1), Biomedical Engineering (3), Geological Sciences (1) and Behavioral Neuroscience (1). BD Fellows came from different LSAMP institutions - Binghamton University (4), Northeastern University (2), South Dakota School of Mines & Technology (1), California State University- Fullerton (1), Bennet College (1), Molloy College (1), Bowie State University (1), University of Texas- Arlington (1), and Rochester Institute of Technology (1), Wright State University (1).

 

9 of the 14 BD Fellows are completing their Ph.D. programs at BU. 8 of those 9 BD Fellows successfully conferred Masters degrees en route to the Ph.D. BD Fellows average GPA was 3.54.

 

The 5 BD Fellows who did not stay for their Ph.D. have entered jobs in industry or education. 3 BD Fellows have procured external experiences within healthcare, oil and gas, and the Department of Defense to enhance their Ph.D. research.

 

The BD Fellows attended ten different conferences while supported by BD funds, presenting their research at nine of those conferences. The BD Fellows served as mentors for high school and undergraduate students in the BU Upward Bound, Upward Bound Math and Science, CSTEP, EOP, LSAMP, McNair, and SSS programs, encouraging underrepresented minority students to pursue STEM degrees through University visitation programs and recruitment events.

 

Intellectual merit: The project added to the current efforts by SUNY LSAMP to build research capacity in STEM education in the area of graduate education. The lessons learned were put into the context of broader issues of systemic change and disseminated to a broad national audience.

 

Broader Impacts: Using the lessons learned from this project, we continued to develop and refine strategies that will increase the recruitment and retention of UREP STEM graduate students. These strategies may increase the number of UREP STEM students who successfully complete doctoral degrees in STEM disciplines and make changes in STEM departmental culture and practice. The success of the BD Fellows has informed best practices to recruit, retain, and support UREP STEM graduate students outside of BD. The BD Fellows’ successes facilitate and encourage conversations with faculty and researchers regarding broadening the scope and considering new paradigms to evaluate talented students for doctoral programs addressing systemic change.
